importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 17, 2025, indicating the current state of electricity cost trends and AI-related demand growth as of that time.
The average price of electricity in America has increased by 13% since 2022, marking a baseline for tracking rising costs.
Data center electricity consumption was 4.4% of U.S. electricity use in 2023, serving as a baseline for projected increases by 2028.
A December 2024 Department of Energy report projected that data centers will consume 6.7% to 12% of U.S. electricity by 2028.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article projects a significant rise in data center electricity consumption, from 4.4% in 2023 to 6.7–12% by 2028, indicating a long-term trend in energy demand driven by AI development.

keyTakeAways: The rise in electricity bills is being driven by increased demand from AI-powered data centers, which are consuming more electricity than ever before.
AI development has led to an 'explosion in demand' for computing power, requiring more energy-intensive infrastructure and infrastructure upgrades.
Data center electricity consumption is projected to grow from 4.4% in 2023 to 6.7–12% by 2028, according to the U.S. Department of Energy.
Tech giants like Meta and Microsoft are investing heavily in data centers — Meta spent $17 billion and Microsoft $24.2 billion in one quarter — fueling increased electricity demand.
Some regions, like Oregon, are implementing policy changes to require data centers to pay for their grid strain, preventing cost shifts to residential consumers.
Electricity prices are rising due to infrastructure costs, severe weather, and the growing power needs of AI systems, with some areas seeing electricity cost increases of up to 267% in five years.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Electricity bills are rising across the U.S., with increases driven by a surge in demand from AI-powered data centers. A 13% rise in average electricity prices since 2022 reflects broader trends, but AI is now a major catalyst — with tech giants like Meta and Microsoft spending billions on data center construction. The Department of Energy projects data centers will consume 6.7% to 12% of U.S. electricity by 2028. Experts say this surge, fueled by the computational demands of advanced AI systems, is straining the power grid and pushing prices up, especially in regions near data centers. Some states, like Oregon, are addressing the issue by requiring data centers to pay for their grid strain, to protect residential consumers from cost increases.
title: Is AI really making electricity bills higher? Here’s what the experts say
